column1: A gene is a locus (or region) of DNA which is made up of nucleotides and is the molecular unit of heredity. The transmission of genes to an organism's offspring is the basis of the inheritance of phenotypic traits. Most biological traits are under the influence of polygenes (many different genes) as well as the gene–environment interactions. Some genetic traits are instantly visible
column2: such as eye colour or number of limbs
column6: or the thousands of basic biochemical processes that comprise life. In July 2016
column7: scientists reported identifying a set of 355 genes from the Last Universal Common Ancestor (LUCA) of all organisms living on Earth.Genes can acquire mutations in their sequence
column10: in the population. These alleles encode slightly different versions of a protein
column11: which cause different phenotype traits. Colloquial usage of the term "having a gene" (e.g.
column13: hair colour gene") typically refers to having a different allele of the gene. Genes evolve due to natural selection or survival of the fittest of the alleles.
